awd_titl_txt: CAREER:Functional contributions of lateral parietal cortex to episodic memory
awd_abstract_narration:
It is a remarkable feature of human memory that people can vividly re-experience events from the past by bringing these experiences back to mind on command. Over the past two decades, neuroimaging studies have consistently found that the parietal cortex plays a role in this ability to re-experience the past. However, the specific way in which parietal cortex contributes to human memory remains a topic of  substantial debate. With the support of this CAREER award, Dr. Kuhl will use a combination of functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), electroencephalography (EEG), and advanced statistical approaches to determine how memories are encoded in distributed patterns of activity in parietal cortex. Studies will determine how parietal representations of memories are shaped by behavioral goals, how these representations evolve over time, and how parietal cortex interacts with other brain regions during acts of remembering. The research will culminate in a computational understanding of the role of parietal cortex in memory. This will critically inform theories of human memory and will be relevant to understanding how and why memory function is impaired. Additionally, research findings and analysis approaches from these studies will be used to generate a novel, project-based math curriculum for a local middle school, helping to raise interest in and awareness of STEM careers. 

In this project, Human fMRI studies will be used to identify how memory representations are encoded in distributed patterns of activity in parietal cortex. Forward encoding models will be used to predict the activity pattern that a given stimulus will elicit in parietal cortex. These models will be based on the semantic properties of that stimulus (i.e., stimulus content) and the "memory status" of that stimulus (i.e., whether the stimulus is remembered from a past experience). Dr. Kuhl will then test how parietal memory representations are influenced by top-down behavioral goals. It is predicted that compared to representations in sensory cortex, parietal representations will be more sensitive to behavioral goals. This prediction is motivated by a theoretical perspective wherein parietal cortex functions as an interface between sensory cortex and prefrontal cortex. Related to this prediction, EEG decoding studies will track the timing with which memory representations emerge in parietal cortex. It is expected that parietal representations will temporally lag those in sensory areas, and will exhibit coherence with prefrontal representations leading up to behavioral decisions. The overarching goal is to develop a new theoretical account of how parietal cortex contributes to memory via internal computations and interactions with other brain regions. The research activities will also provide insight into how parietal cortex contributes to cognitive processes more generally.

por.por_cntn:
Human neuroimaging studies of episodic memory have consistently observed that lateral parietal cortex (LPC) is involved in successful remembering, inspiring much debate about the functional contributions that LPC makes to memory. Because LPC involvement in memory retrieval is so ubiquitous and is observed across a broad range of content types (i.e., different modalities and categories of memoranda), it has traditionally been assumed that LPC plays a content-general role in episodic memory–in other words, that it is agnostic to the type of information being held in memory. However, this view has been challenged by recent evidence that LPC memory signals also contain information about remembered content. This has raised new questions about how LPC combines memory-related and content-related information. With the support of this award, we conducted a series of experiments using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) in order to establish how LPC combines memory-related signals with representations of remembered content. Collectively, our experiments establish several important findings. First, we find that although there is a high degree of spatial overlap between memory-related and content-related signals in LPC, these two forms of information are additively combined (not interactively combined). In other words, these signals are overlapping, but independent in LPC. In contrast, in visual cortical areas, memory-related and content-related signals are interactive—namely, memory-related information in visual cortex is inherently based on content representations. Second, we find that content representations in LPC markedly differ during visual perception vs. memory retrieval. Strikingly, LPC content representations are stronger during memory retrieval (i.e., when content information is entirely derived from memory) than during visual perception (i.e., when content information is visually accessible). This pattern of results contrasts sharply with content representations in visual cortical areas which are stronger during perception than during memory. These findings suggest a “transformation” of information from perceptual representations in visual cortex to memory representations in LPC. Third, and finally, we find that content representations in LPC are (a) uniquely sensitive to top-down goals and (b) uniquely predictive of behavioral memory outcomes. These findings suggest that LPC content representations serve as an interface between perceptual representations in visual cortex and top-down goals and behavioral decisions. Collectively, our research findings provide fundamental new insight into how LPC combines memory-related and content-related information to guide adaptive behavior.

Complementing our research activities—which placed strong emphasis on using advanced mathematical techniques for data analysis—we also partnered with multiple organizations, teachers, and graduate students to support math enrichment for middle school students. Specifically, we engaged in a project-based learning unit with math and science teachers at a local STEM-themed middle school and we partnered with faculty and graduate students supporting a unique math program for middle school students (Math Circle) at the University of Oregon. These broader impact activities fulfilled our objective of enhancing math awareness and interest among school-aged children and will hopefully inspire future applications of math in scientific research.
